ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to analyze Caribbean diasporic history and identity through the medium of literature. I came to really appreciate the breadth of literature we read and discussed in this course, which encompassed queer and trans literature, poetry, and magical realism.
Racialization, gender studies, theories of colonialism and diaspora, labor systems
Learned a lot more about terms like "diaspora," "nation," and "home" and the literature we read really helped me think about myself/my own life as well as my thesis project!
We read several texts by authors from across the Caribbean diaspora and also learned about the historical/geographic contexts in which these works were produced.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Our small seminar size really allowed for robust discussions; Professor Habchi was also a wonderful discussion facilitator and made everyone feel like their contributions were substantial. A book a week felt at times overwhelming, but all of the literature assigned in this class was genuinely enjoyable to read, so it didn't feel too overwhelming. Can't think of any weaknesses other than that the first 2-3 weeks of the course might be difficult for students not familiar with critical/postcolonial theory, as the theoretical readings the first few weeks were on the denser side.

The syllabus is just so good, and Professor Habchi is very nice. Class never felt intimidating. As for weaknesses, I think more structure to class discussion would help over Zoom (purely because people are less willing to talk), although at the same time, I appreciated how free-flowing the conversation was. A novel a week is already a hefty reading load (definitely an enjoyable one), but I also sometimes wished that we had continued to put theoretical texts in conversation with the fiction. After the first several weeks, we weren't assigned any more theory (not to reinforce that arbitrary divide between 'theory' and 'non-theory'), which makes sense because we had 200-300 pages of reading from the novels. So I'm not sure what a workaround would be. Maybe even just making it a priority to ground our analysis of the novel in the theory we had read?
The seminar discussions were fantastic and helped me engage with texts more effectively.
The syllabus was great! I just wished we had more time to discuss the texts and more check-ins with prof.Habchi
This was a great class! The readings were incredible, the workload was manageable, and I always gained a lot from our discussions. Hard to name something to improve.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I appreciated how Professor Habchi was understanding if students had to turn their cameras off at times because of WiFi issues or other personal reasons.
Prof.Habchi kept classes super engaging. I wish, however, that we could've taken more breaks for a very long seminar in the afternoon.
This class went very smoothly, even in a virtual format! Our presentations and seminar discussions all worked well on Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, and especially if you are an ER&M major. If you are committed to reading all of the assigned novels, you will find that they are genuinely a joy to read and discuss, and Professor Habchi is one of the kindest professors out there.

Yes! Professor Habchi is absolutely fantastic, and facilitates class discussions very well. In the beginning of the semester, we learned about theories of colonization and diaspora which grounded our future discussions on literature. The essays were also great exercises to engage with texts and incorporate outside sources to deepen our analysis.
Yes! The syllabus is amazing and Prof.Habchi is a great, engaging professor.
Absolutely! I'd recommend this class to anyone who's interested in learning more about the Caribbean through literature.
